posts.title: Afar, we stand......
posts.text: Welcome to Ir Trichloride’s Personal Blog!This is my first blog article.Let’s talk about Existentialism. THE FOLLOWING IS WRITTEN BY DEEPSEEK###Existence, Freedom, and Sartre’s Famous Line Existentialism, a philosophical movement prominent in the 20th century, centers on the individual’s radical freedom and responsibility in a universe without inherent meaning or divine blueprint. It argues that existence precedes essence—we are born without a predefined purpose and must actively create our own values and identity through our choices and actions. The French philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre is a key figure in this school of thought. His dense yet powerful statement, “We are condemned to be free,” perfectly captures existentialism’s daunting core. This phrase is often misunderstood. “Condemned” suggests a sentence, a burden—not a celebration. For Sartre, freedom is not a pleasant gift but an inescapable condition of human existence. We are “thrown” into the world and are absolutely responsible for crafting our own life’s path through every decision we make, large or small. This condemnation stems from the absence of any external authority (like God or fixed moral laws) to justify our choices. We cannot blame fate, genetics, or circumstances. This immense responsibility generates profound anguish, as we are acutely aware that our choices define not only ourselves but also, by example, humanity as a whole. Every commitment we make creates a version of what a human “should” be. Thus, Sartre’s line forces us to confront a sobering truth: we are unforgivably free. There is no escape from the necessity of choosing and, therefore, from the weight of authorship over our own lives. This insight remains profoundly relevant, challenging us to live authentically—to acknowledge our liberty and own our actions without excuse.
